title: Fall in Love With the Process, but Don’t Lose Sight of the End Goal

particles.text: I’ll admit that this is somewhat of an unorthodox article for what I would normally write for The Bit Whisperer, but this is a topic that is near and dear to my heart.  Goals are an important part of life; they are part of what makes life worth living in the first place.  The nature and scope of these goals can vary wildly. They can be small goals such as finishing the house chores or simply getting out of bed in the morning.  Other goals may be incredibly lofty such as starting a business, publishing a book, or becoming fluent in a foreign language.

Celebrate the journey, then celebrate the destination.  Fall in love with the process, but don’t lose sight of the end goal.  These are two of my favorite phrases when it comes to tackling all kinds of goals, especially the very lofty, long-running ones.  Those two phrases represent a certain mindset, one that has gotten me through most long-running goals I have had in life.  It is a mindset that has done a lot for me in general.

There is one mistake that people so often make: focusing too much on the end goal, thus neglecting to take joy in the process. They condition their happiness on the accomplishment of these goals.  It’s the thought of "I’ll be happy when…"
"I’ll be happy when I finally lose 50 pounds."
"I’ll be happy when I finally make $100,000 per year."
"I’ll be happy when I finally earn that degree."
"I’ll be happy when I finally finish that project."
"I’ll be happy when I finally publish that book."
"I’ll be happy when I finally publish that app."

That is such a toxic and demoralizing mentality to have.  It’s easy to become discouraged when focusing on how far away then end goal is.  It is important to pay attention to the process; appreciating each and every incremental step you take on that journey toward accomplishing that goal.  Another one of my favorite quotes comes to mind here: "How do you eat an elephant?  One bite at a time!"  It’s necessary to ditch the "I’ll be happy when..." mentality and substitute it with "I’m glad I made progress today."
"I’m glad I went to the gym today."
"I’m glad I finished that homework today."
"I’m glad I wrote that paragraph today."
"I’m glad I got that unit test passing today."

However, it is also important to not fall to the other extreme: fixating on the process so much that we lose sight of the end goal.  This is a surefire way to cause one to fall into a depressing grind and lose direction.  It’s important to balance both.  Again... fall in love with the process, but don’t lose sight of the end goal.  Celebrate the small, incremental wins so you can celebrate the end result.  Stop and smell the flowers once in a while, but don’t forget where you’re going.
As you read this, you might have a certain goal or set of goals in mind.  Whatever that goal might be, I believe in you; you got this!
